The Cabinet held a preliminary discussion inregard to legislation for the forthcoming Sessionof Parliament. There was a general realisationthat the amount of legislation to be proposed inthe King's Speech must be kept within narrow limits,in order to avoid congestion of Parliamentary time.The Prime Minister indicated that it would hardly be possible to avoid an Autumn Session, which,however, he hoped might be limited to a fortnight.Suggestions which had been made at previousdiscussions on this question were repeated and pressed, namely, that the debates on the Eing'sSpeech were unduly prolonged and that an unnecessaryamount of time was devoted to "the discussion ofSupplementary Estimates. In this connection theCabinet were informed that there was every prospectof the Supplementary Estimates being fewer in number and less in the amounts involved than in formeryears.There was general agreement that in any event the Representation of the People (Equal Franchise)Bill must be pressed forward. The question of Rouseof Lords Reform was also mentioned as a subject which would have to be taken up before long.Among the Bills the merits of which wouldhave to be weighed at the Cabinet's next discxissionon this question, were mentioned the Factories Bill,the Children Bill (Paper C.P.-5 (28)), and a slum clearance Bill, The Cabinet were also informed that two days of Parliamentary time would probably haveto be given to the Prayer Book measure.A. suggestion was made that as the next GeneralElection would probably not/take place before May,1929, it might be possible to reserve one considerable treasure for the year 1929-30.With a viev: to a comprehensive discussion othe legislation of the Session at a Meeting of thCabinet on Wednesday, January 25th, the cabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary should be instructed to ask all cabinet ministers to forward a list ofthe Bills they would like tohave considered for introductionduring the coming parliamentary session:(b) that the Chief Whip should beasked to provide a sketch time-table showing the amount of timelikely to be available for legis-lation. The First Lord of the Admiralty called theattention of the Cabinet to information published in "The Shipping World" containing some details ofthe Cabinet decision, referred to in the margin, inregard to the Naval Programme. Some of the dailynewspapers, Mr Bridgeman reported, containedmisleading information on the subject. In thecircumstances, he thought that an official announce-ment of the Government's policy ought to be made.A short discussion took place in regard tothe leakage of information in regard to theServices, It was stated that there had been aleakage in regard to the work of the Sub-Committeeof the Committee of Imperial Defence on Cavalry.Mention was also made of the leakage of Air Forceinformation, which had transpired during theespionage trial now in progress. The suggestion was made that the leakage was apt to occur at theService Clubs.The Cabinet agreed That the First Lord of the Admiralty,in consultation wj.th the Chancellorof the Exchequer,'should draw up anofficial statement in regard to theNaval Construction Programme as approved by the Cabinet on December22nd, 1927, and should issue it tothe Press., Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,January 18, 1928.
